supporting.text: Not all cancer patients are physically or mentally impaired to the extent that qualifies them for disability benefits under legal standards.

attacks.text: Not all cancer patients are physically or mentally impaired to the extent that qualifies them for disability benefits under legal standards.
Many cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy, cause severe side effects like fatigue and cognitive impairment, which often meet disability criteria.
Disability benefits often require documented proof of impairment, which not all cancer patients can provide even if they experience symptoms.
Some jurisdictions automatically qualify certain cancer diagnoses for disability benefits regardless of individual impairment levels.

supporting.text: Many cancer patients continue to work during treatment or after recovery, depending on the type and stage of cancer.

attacks.text: Many cancer patients continue to work during treatment or after recovery, depending on the type and stage of cancer.
Some cancer treatments are highly debilitating, making it impossible for patients to work regardless of cancer type or stage.
Even in cases where treatment is debilitating, workplace accommodations or remote work options may allow some patients to continue employment.
Workplace accommodations are not universally available, especially in physically demanding jobs or countries with weak labor protections.
Disability benefits often require formal medical certification, which some recovering patients may not qualify for despite residual impairments.
Statistical data shows over 40% of cancer survivors report work-related limitations even 5 years post-treatment (per National Cancer Institute studies).

supporting.text: Disability eligibility depends on specific criteria set by government or insurance programs, which not all cancer patients meet.

attacks.text: Disability eligibility depends on specific criteria set by government or insurance programs, which not all cancer patients meet.
Many cancer patients are automatically eligible for disability due to the severity and chronic nature of their condition.
Automatic eligibility is often limited to specific advanced or terminal stages of cancer, excluding early-stage patients.
Some countries have universal disability coverage for cancer patients regardless of stage or severity.
Universal coverage is rare and often comes with long waiting periods or bureaucratic hurdles.

supporting.text: Some cancer patients with severe or advanced stages may qualify for disability due to the debilitating effects of the disease or treatment.

attacks.text: Some cancer patients with severe or advanced stages may qualify for disability due to the debilitating effects of the disease or treatment.
Not all cancer patients have severe or advanced stages, and many continue to work without needing disability benefits.
Early-stage cancer patients often respond well to treatment and may not experience debilitating effects.
Even some advanced-stage patients may not qualify for disability if their condition is managed effectively.

supporting.text: The ability to work varies widely among cancer patients, with some experiencing minimal disruption to their daily activities.

attacks.text: The ability to work varies widely among cancer patients, with some experiencing minimal disruption to their daily activities.
Many cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy and radiation, cause severe side effects that often prevent patients from working.
Even with severe side effects, some patients continue to work remotely or with accommodations.
Certain cancers, like early-stage skin cancer, often require minimal treatment and rarely impact work ability.
Early-stage cancers are often exceptions, and most cancer patients face significant disability due to advanced stages or aggressive treatments.
